thread.title: Rangers down Blue Jackets, 5-2, to remain perfect
thread.title_full: Rangers down Blue Jackets, 5-2, to remain perfect

title: Rangers down Blue Jackets, 5-2, to remain perfect
text:
Buy this photo ASSOCIATED PRESS Rangers center Oscar Lindberg (24) celebrates his second goal with teammates during the first period against the Columbus Blue Jackets on Saturday. 
NEW YORK — The plan has seemingly worked, as clearly evidenced in the Rangers’ memorable home opener. 
Henrik Lundqvist’s preseason schedule was altered to give him more time to fine tune his technique before playing with an eye to the Rangers getting off to a quicker start this season. 
So even though the Rangers opened with three games in four nights, they and their franchise goalie are 3-0-0 after a 5-2 win over the Blue Jackets Saturday at Madison Square Garden as they swept the home-and-home series on back-to-back nights. 
The Rangers had rallied for a 4-2 win at Nationwide Arena on Friday after starting their season by spoiling the Blackhawks’ Stanley Cup banner raising ceremony with a 3-2 win at Chicago on Wednesday. Last season, the Rangers opened 1-3-0 with a similarly condensed schedule to start the season and were still 11-10-4 early in December before finishing with an NHL-high 113 points. 
Lundqvist made 37 saves — his third straight game with 30-plus saves — but his bid for his first shutout this season ended with center Ryan Johansen shoveling in a goal at 4:35 of the third period to cut the Rangers’ lead to 5-1. 
Rookie Oscar Lindberg scored twice in the first period, giving him four goals already. 
“Obviously, he can skate in the NHL,” coach Alain Vigneault said. 
Lundqvist was spectacular all game even on the rare times he was caught out of position. 
That came late in the second period, as Lundqvist skated out of his crease to his left to corral a Blue Jackets’ dump-in. But the puck took a bad bounce off the boards, leaving it dangling at the net as Johansen swiped at it. 
But Lundqvist dove and managed to knock the puck out of the air and away from the net with his paddle. 
The Blue Jackets started Saturday night’s game still apparently shell-shocked by the Rangers’ three-goal barrage late in the third period on Friday night. Lindberg scored twice in the opening 5:12 and Dominic Moore made it 3-0 at 5:48.
